name: market for heat, from steam, in chemical industry | heat, from steam, in chemical industry | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7976/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for  'heat, from steam, in chemical industry', in the geography of Europe.;This market contains no transport or losses, as they are irrelevant for the delivered product.;This product represents heat measured in MJ. The heat is produced with the average fuel mix used in the chemical and petrochemical industry. It is to be used for heat energy in an average chemical plant. ;This market is supplied exclusively by the activity "steam production, as energy carrier, in chemical industry". Other activities that produce steam as byproduct are excluded, so that consumers of steam get by default supplied with steam produced using the average energy mix that is estimated to be used for steam production in the chemical industry within the geography of this market.;;The production volume is set equal to that of the supplying transforming activity. Based on data published by Cefic (2016), the fuel and power consumption in the EU chemical industry in 2010 amounted to 53.6994 million tonnes of oil equivalent. Roughly 40% of the energy is assumed to be delivered in the form of steam, based on data for the United States (JISEA, 2016).;;References:;Cefic (2016). The European Chemical Industry - Facts & Figures 2016, Chart 5.1 - Fuel and power consumption in the EU chemical industry.;The Joint Institute for Strategic Energy Analysis (JISEA) (2016). Generation and Use of Thermal Energy in the U.S. Industrial Sector and Opportunities to Reduce its Carbon Emissions. National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), www.nrel.gov/publications.

This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'heat, from steam, in chemical industry',  within the geography of Europe.

This activity ends with the supply of  heat, from steam, in chemical industry', to the consumers of this product. Transport or losses are considered irrelevant for this product.
